title: 112_s1308
content:
The Act is titled the "Protecting Children From Internet Pornographers Act of 2011." It addresses the financial facilitation of access to child pornography. The "Protecting Children From Internet Pornographers Act of 2011" amends Chapter 95 of title 18, United States Code by adding a new section (Sec. 1960A) that criminalizes conducting financial transactions to facilitate access to child pornography. The offense carries a penalty of up to 20 years imprisonment or a fine. This section does not apply to transactions conducted with the consent of law enforcement agencies. The "Protecting Children From Internet Pornographers Act of 2011" adds section 1960A to title 18, United States Code, criminalizing financial facilitation of access to child pornography. Amendments to section 1956(c)(7)(D) include adding 1960A as a money laundering predicate. SEC. 4. RETENTION OF CERTAIN RECORDS BY ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATION SERVICE PROVIDERS.

A provider of electronic communication service must retain network address logs for at least 18 months. Records should be stored securely to protect customer privacy.

SEC. 5. NO CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST A PROVIDER DISCLOSING INFORMATION UNDER THIS CHAPTER. Section 2703(e) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "retaining records or" after "other specified persons for". Section 2707(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include ", or the requirement to retain records under section 2703(h)," after "section 2703(f)". Section 566(e)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the issuance of administrative subpoenas for investigating unregistered sex offenders. Section 1514 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for protective orders for minor witnesses or victims to prevent harassment or intimidation that may affect their willingness to participate in a case. The amendment to Section 1514 of title 18, United States Code, includes provisions for protective orders for minor witnesses or victims to prevent harassment or intimidation that may affect their willingness to participate in a case. The court may issue an ex parte emergency protective order in advance of a hearing if exigent circumstances are present, with a hearing required within 14 days. The amendment to Section 1514 of title 18, United States Code allows for protective orders for minor witnesses or victims to prevent harassment. Violating such an order can result in a fine, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. The term "course of conduct" refers to a series of acts indicating a continuity of purpose, while "harassment" is defined as a serious act or course of conduct directed at a specific person. The term 'intimidation' refers to a serious act directed at a specific person causing fear and serving no legitimate purpose. The term 'immediate family member' includes grandchildren. The term 'serious act' means a single threatening, retaliatory, harassing, or violent conduct likely to influence a victim's willingness. The term 'specific person' in Federal criminal cases refers to a victim, witness, or their immediate family member. Courts presume that sharing personal information online about a specific person is not legitimate unless authorized by the person, for news reporting, locating a missing person, or part of a government effort. Sharing personal information online about a specific person is not legitimate unless authorized by the person, for news reporting, locating a missing person, or part of a government effort to locate a fugitive or person of interest in a criminal, antiterrorism, or national security investigation. SEC. 9. SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission has the authority to review and amend Federal sentencing guidelines to include penalty increases for certain offenses, such as those involving physical injury to a person under 18 years of age to obstruct justice. The United States Sentencing Commission can increase penalties by up to 12 levels for offenses involving physical injury to a person under 18 years of age to obstruct justice. SEC. 10 enhances penalties for possession of child pornography involving prepubescent minors or those under 12 years of age, with fines and imprisonment for up to 20 years. SEC. 11 introduces administrative subpoenas. Section 3486(a)(1) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include an unregistered sex offender conducted by the United States Marshals Service. The term 'sex offender' is defined as an individual required to register. The term 'sex offender' refers to an individual required to register under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act. Technical amendments are made to Section 3486(a) of title 18, United States Code.
